fields.Title of Contribution: The population interplay of two malaria vectors in NE Uganda and their measured declines with vector control
fields.Journal: Malaria Journal or American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene
fields.Description/Abstract:
Entomological surveillance has been a component of an ongoing, multi-year study
of malaria transmission and its control in a high transmission area of NE Uganda.
We report on seasonal and locational trends among the two primary malarial
vectors taken from 90 sentinel huts in three connected subcounties of the
Katakwi district. As part of the study, two of three subcounties receive indoor
residual spraying with pirimiphos methyl, alone or in combination with a mass
drug administration campaign of dihydroartemisinin-piperaquine. Mosquitoes in
these districts, with and without these interventions, are collected for a single
night at monthly intervals with CDC light traps for nearly three years. Temporal
trends and spatial mapping for these surveillance hut collections, and those
subcounty-wide, are reported. A biannual seasonal trend for sequential,
coordinated emergence of members of the A. gambiae s. l. complex and A.
funestus is observed. This is an interspecific interaction, with two sequentially
independent, annual vector density peaks found, each dominated by a single
species. A spatially complex picture of the mosquito densities is also observed
though both species appear to largely share the same locales. The intervention impacts of IRS are very apparent on the mosquito densities, with percentage reductions generally around 70-80% compared to the neighboring regions without vector control. These results suggest that in Katakwi the vector control efforts have been effective, should be seasonally performed, and in such a high transmission environment may not benefit from focal targeting.
